question.para: How do I find a package or command?

answer.para: Mostly, it's not hard, but some things can lead quite a chase.
To get a command, you must know what package it's from. Sometimes this is obvious; when it's not, a search on either or will usually provide the answer.
Once you know the package, searching for foo will usually turn up a freshmeat page with links to an URL which may have newer releases not reported to freshmeat.

Searching for +foo +index +lsm tends to find directory listings with an LSM (Linux Software Map) file. The LSM file will list an official distribution point which is likelier to have the most recent version or at least a more recent LSM file which will list an even more recent distribution point.
If the search results are clogged with links to RPM packages and Debian's archives, try +foo +index +lsm -RPM -debian If there are too few results try dropping the "+lsm" and "+index".
Hits on are often good. To find them specifically, use foo site:ibiblio.org
If the latest release is old, Debian or an SRPM may have helpful patches, and there may be a modern replacement for the package which a freshmeat search will likely find.
